Award.AwardTitle: A Sociology of Testing, Diagnosis and Autism Spectrum Disorder

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Introduction

The purpose of this project is to study the testing and diagnosis of children who are being considered for an Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). Since the early 1990s, there has been a huge upsurge in ASD diagnosis. Sociological and epidemiological studies can account for much of the increased prevalence. However, little attention has been paid to the concrete ways in which clinicians and the child are engaged in the examination process. Attention also needs to be given to what happens after completing the exams with a child; how clinicians consult with one another about their findings, determine a diagnosis, and present that diagnosis to parents and other caretakers. Such considerations should be extended to how family, legal, economic and other factors affect diagnosis.

Intellectual Merit

There are three parts to our study corresponding to the three sets of concerns indicated above. The first aim is to do a sociology of testing, understanding the organized social interactions and collaborative skills by which clinicians and children engage in examination tasks. The second aim focuses on the narrations associated with what clinicians have found in testing, the discussion of those findings and attempts resolve any discrepancies among themselves, and the presentation of their diagnostic conclusions to family members and other caretakers such as educators. The third aim is to explore how, in their testing and diagnostic determinations, clinicians and caretakers may orient to social contexts surrounding autism diagnosis including family, legal, educational, administrative, and economic factors.

Potential Broader Impacts

This study of interactions in the testing and diagnostic process potentially means better understanding of ability/disability and greater inclusion of ASD individuals in society. It additionally provides for the discovery of unanticipated avenues and future research into the causes, consequences and treatment of ASD. Finally, the project also involves the training of graduate student sociologists as Science and Technology Scholars concerned with ASD.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A Sociology of Testing, Diagnosis, and Autism Spectrum Disorder

The purpose of this project was to study the testing and diagnosis of children who are being considered for an Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD). 

Our approach to these topics was to do an ethnographic field study (by way of observation and interview) in a clinic for ASD, video recording its testing and diagnostic processes, transcribing the data, and analyzing the patterns of talk and social interaction that we found. Our subfield in sociology is known as ethnomethodology and conversation analysis, which began its development in the 1960s, and is now a large social scientific area that combines not only sociology, but also applied linguistics, sociolinguistics, and communications studies.

1. Our sociology of testing has meant understanding the organized social interactions and collaborative skills by which clinicians and children engage in examination tasks. We have developed two interrelated concepts relevant to diagnostic testing. One is the “interactional substrate,” which refers to all the activities that a clinician and child engage in with one another to be able to generate a desired testing outcome (i.e. a score). The other is “concrete competence,” which refers to the practices that are part of the interactional substrate and indicate how a child orients to the tasks set before him or her. For the most part, concrete competence does not get measured, even though it’s necessary for a child to deploy such competence in order to perform any task that the clinician and test require, and regardless of whether the child is able to perform the task (i.e., get it “right”).

 2. Our sociology of diagnosis show how, through narrating what their tests have found, and considering other sources of information on a child (such as interviews with parents), clinicians discuss findings and resolve any discrepancies among themselves, and then present their diagnostic conclusions to family members and other caretakers such as educators. We found that and analyze a narrative structure for determining ASD diagnosis. The narrative structure for diagnosis is depicted in Figure 1.

Figure 1 Narrative Structure for Diagnosis in Interaction

A. Prefaces: setting up the stories to follow

B. Stories:

1) Instantiation: single episode, particular time and place

2) Tendency: "multiples" & measurements of a given behavior

C. Typifications: relatively static, categorical assertions and assessments

D. Story recipiency: different clinicians, family members, school personnel, others, affect how the narrative is assembled, understood, accepted

As illustrated, diagnostic narratives for ASD include, (A) the preface, and then two distinct story types (B). These are (1) stories about concrete ‘‘instantiations,’’ which portray single episodes of conduct and their particulars, and (2) stories that propose ‘‘tendencies.” Our research has shown that tendency stories outweigh instantiation stories by a ratio of about 4 to 1. Subsequent to, or as part of such stories, clinicians also produce (C) “typifications,” which usually indicate, adumbrate, or sometimes formally articulate, a particular diagnosis such as ASD. Those who are the "audience" for such stories affect how they are told and also indicate whether they align or not to the complete stories or set of stories. This is what is meant by "story recipiency."

Two dissertations and one master’s thesis were completed from this project. Members of my lab and I have published about a dozen papers, and (with one former graduate student who is now a post-doc elsewhere), I am publishing a book concerned with testing and diagnosis. We have also given talks about our research at many scientific meetings and in community settings as well.

Now we are interested in doing more with this research. We think that our approach and findings may provide information about what goes on during testing and diagnosis that could enhance the continuing efforts to make test instruments, and the overall diagnostic process, more accurate and individualized. For example, although both tendency and instantiation story types can be probative or evidential for autism diagnosis, instantiation stories have unique qualities that bear further investigation. In addition, although we have expertise in studying and analyzing the important details of social interaction, we lack the expertise to determine the relevance of interaction studies for enhancing diagnosis and the associated recommendations for a child and his or her experiences at home, school, or elsewhere. Consequently, we are partnering with scholars who have more clinical experience working with individuals on the autism spectrum, and others who have expertise in instrument design, to see how our research endeavors can have practical impacts and enlarge the capacities of both persons with ASD and the different social groupings to which they belong.

As we continue, we also keep our sights on making our research relevant to science and technology studies, both theoretical and empirically.
